pr_title: Add optional field access and conditional expression parsing

timeline.message: Add test cases for elvis conditional expression parsing

timeline.bodyText:
Assuming qualified-identifier gets the higher precedence a ? b:c : d passes as anticipated.
But, If we consider simple a ? b : c, it cannot be parsed as b:c is parsed as a qualified-identifier.
That's problem I'm facing now
timeline.author: lochana-chathura

replies.bodyText:
I see. May be we would have to special case that. i.e: in expr1 ? expr2 : expr3 if colon is missing, we check whether expr2 is a qualified identifier or not. If yes, we can split it back and treat it as the expr2:expr3. Not the cleanest way, but that would work i think.
WDYT?
replies.author: SupunS

replies.bodyText:
Well, expr2 is not always a qualified identifier, when we have this problem.
For example in a ? b : c+d, we have a binary expression.
So depend on the situation we will have to check their children or children of children or .... for a qualified identifier.
Sometimes there cloud be more than one qualified identifier. Splitting and re-parsing is not possible in such complex cases.
replies.author: lochana-chathura

replies.bodyText:
Since we have an LL(k) parser I was thinking something like this.
When parsing a qualified identifier, we can check whether there's a spare colon ahead until lower precedence operator or end of expression token is reached. If there's no spare colon ahead, we will not parse the qualified identifier, instead only capture the identifier.
We will have to use a flag to identify whether we are in a conditional-expr when doing the above thing.
Another problem in this approach is we could have mapping-constructors when checking over the tokens ahead. So we have to make sure that we are looking for a spare colon which is not surrounded by {  }  tokens.
WDYT?
replies.author: lochana-chathura

replies.bodyText:
Ok.
I think we have to treat a ? b : c as an invalid code. Because according to ballerina-platform/ballerina-spec#523, b:c is a var ref.
If someone want to make it working, they have to use parenthesis like:  a ? (b) : c.
That will simplify many things.
replies.author: SupunS

replies.bodyText: Ok great. Then no trouble at all.
replies.author: lochana-chathura
